column3: Established in 2003 Ambassador Theater is an independent site that brings together into one place a complete guide to all the theatrical, musical and performance arts events at Ambassador Theater venues across the United States.

The American Folk Art Museum is the premier institution devoted to the aesthetic appreciation of traditional folk art and creative expressions of contemporary self-taught artists from the United States and abroad. The museum preserves, conserves, and interprets a comprehensive collection of the highest quality, with objects dating from the eighteenth century to the present.
Scientific research and education institution, with collections of more than 32 million specimens and artifacts.
once a secret scenester meeting place, this beautiful West Village bar caters to locals and out-of-towners alike.
sit at the bar for great people-watching at this perennial favorite SoHo French bistro
Pretty Chelsea wine bar serving light Italian fare

Following a “ravishing” $16 million restoration, this UWS “music institution” has maintained its “rock ’n’ roll spirit” during an 84-year run as one of the city’s “premier concert venues”; whether for a jazz concert or “dad rock with the Allman Brothers”, there’s “not a bad seat in the house” – though a few nix the “inflated” drink prices.
Amazing piece of history located inside Central Park

BEER PONG pub where you can listen to live music most evenings, you can be surprised of the talent and quality of the more unknown artists that play there but the main event is probably beer pong. Beer Pong is exaclty what is sounds like a mix between Ping pong and beer drinking.
The Bronx Zoo is located in the Bronx borough of New York City, within Bronx Park. It is one of the world's largest metropolitan zoos, with some 4,000 animals
The Brooklyn Bridge opened in 1883. At the time, it was the longest suspension bridge. It has been designated a National Historic Landmark
A public park of the City of New York and a New York City Scenic Landmark.
located in Grand Central Terminal, this formal upscale bar, once the residence of industrialist John W. Campbell, harkens back to the roaring 20’s and is frequented by commuters and tourists alike.

Visiting this “classical music venue” is always a “royal evening out” thanks to its “historic” aura – virtually every great musician has performed here – and “spectacular pinpoint acoustics” (just bear with the “tight seats and steep stairs” in its higher reaches); there are also “fascinating tours” of this Midtown hall that famously offers two means of admittance: “buy a ticket” or “practice, practice, practice.”
Central Park is a public park at the center of Manhattan in New York City. The park initially opened in 1857, on 843 acres (3.41 km2) of city-owned land.

Oasis of wildlife in downtown Manhattan where visitors can encounter more than 1,400 animals in a variety of habitats, including a tropical rain forest to view rare birds and icy Antarctica to view penguins and other chilly creatures.
A Children's Museum located in Upper West Side and a great place for kids
This Art Deco masterpiece is actually no longer the property of the auto manufacturer.

Columbia University was founded in 1754 as King's College by royal charter of King George II of England. It is the oldest institution of higher learning in the New York and the fifth oldest in the US.

This museum devoted to Caribbean and Latin American art and culture reopened in fall 2009 after undergoing a multimillion dollar renovation that yielded updated galleries, a new glass facade, redesigned courtyard, new cafe and an expanded shop; public programs include everything from their permenant collection and film screenings to book clubs and spoken word events.
Ellis Island is the symbol of American immigration and the immigrant experience
The Empire State Building is a 102-story skyscraper located in Midtown Manhattan, New York City, at the intersection of Fifth Avenue and West 34th Street.
if you can find this cozy hangouts low-key entrance and actually get in, but you will be just rewarded by high-quality classic cocktails.
Fifth Avenue is a major thoroughfare in the center of the borough of Manhattan in New York City, United States. It's very famous for shopping with high-end stores populating the street
This Daniel Burnham design got its moniker because, as you might guess, it resembles an iron.
Also known as One World Trade Center, this tower is constructed next to the site of the Twin Towers and will be 1,776 feet high once finished.
The Collection includes some of the best-known paintings by the greatest European artists, major works of sculpture. The Library is a leading site for collecting and provenance research.
While Grand Central Terminal is one of the nations most historical landmarks, it has remained the busiest train station in the country.
Greenwich Village, often referred to in New York as simply "the Village", is a largely residential neighborhood on the west side of Lower Manhattan
A dedication to the men and women at World Trade Center ground zero.
A museum which introduces visitors to photography while also building visual literacy and critical thinking skills

column1: Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum
column3: Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum is one of America’s leading historic, cultural & educational institutions. The mission of the Museum is to honor our heroes, educate the public and inspire our youth.
A small venue that attracts some of the biggest talent in the world. Iridium is best known for its performances of Les Paul and the Les Paul Trio for more than 12 years.

Known again by its original moniker after a “dumb name change” to the Fillmore a few years back, this longtime Gramercy venue is renowned for its “good sound” system and “semi-established” acts; since it remains a “top” choice for “intimate performances”, be prepared for “big lines” out front.
Watch the popular talk show be aired live!
Madison Square Garden is a multi-purpose indoor arena in midtown Manhattan in New York City.
A park located in uptown which features 20th century styles.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art (colloquially The Met), located in New York City, is the largest art museum in the United States

The modern, glass-enclosed Renzo Piano–designed atrium of this Murray Hill museum is meant to capture the spirit of an Italian piazza and provide a contrast to the original, ornate rooms where visitors can almost feel the presence of financier Pierpont Morgan as they take in his world-renowned literary and art collections (which include three Gutenberg bibles); other highlights include a performance hall and two dining spaces – one in the Morgan’s family dining room and the other in the atrium.

From Biedermeier to the Bauhaus, this “refined” UES museum shop showcases a “unique collection” of “quality reproductions” of Austrian and German designs, including serving pieces, jewelry and the Neue Hund collection of “outrageously expensive accoutrements for the dog who has everything”; though “stellar” in quality, merchandise is “priced at astronomical levels”, so just sip a limonade or Viennese hot chocolate at the cafe until you “get rich.”
A theater located next to Times Square which features amazing architecture and a unique charm
The New York Public Library (NYPL) is a public library system in New York City. With nearly 53 million items, the New York Public Library is the second largest in the country
The New York Transit Museum is a museum which displays historical artifacts of the New York City Subway, bus, commuter rail, and bridge and tunnel systems

Directly across from the Gansevoort, this restaurant is best for late night snacking and celebrity spotting. It's a great place to duck into to grab some pomme frittes, mussels, or a steak sandwich before heading back out for another round of play.
Radio City Music Hall is an entertainment venue located in Rockefeller Center in New York City. Its nickname is the Showplace of the Nation
A great spot for a glass of wine (22 in all by glass!). Fairly modern and loud, but still usually a good time.

column1: Ripley's Believe it or Not! Times Square
column3: Visit the Ripley's Believe it or Not! Odditorium in New York City and discover the unusual & the bizarre. We offer our world famous museum with many great exhibits.

Riverbank is the only park of its kind in the Western Hemisphere. Inspired by urban rooftop designs in Japan, this 28-acre multi-level landscaped recreational facility is a state-of-the-art park facility. Rising 69 feet above the Hudson River, Riverbank offers a wide variety of recreational, athletic and arts experiences for all ages, interests and abilities.
Located in the center of Midtown Manhattan, Rockefeller Center or Rockefeller Plaza is a complex of 19 commercial buildings and is one of New York City's top tourist spots
trendy self-described “low life bar and restaurant” that is part of the Lower East Side revival.
A popular shopping district in manhattan.

Since this place opened in 2004, it has been constantly packed. The space is large, yet romatic with pagodas, low golden lighting and a dramatic staircase carved into the center of the room. The food is sublime! Jean-Georges Vongerichten has hit a homerun with this gem.

A “wonder to behold”, this “awe-inspiring” circa-1879 Catholic cathedral opposite Rockefeller Center is a “place of calm in the frantic city” with its “magnificent stained-glass windows”, “beautiful altar” and “amazing” organ; as the seat of the country’s most important bishopric, it has also been the site of a great deal of church and political history; “regardless of one’s religion”, this “beautiful refuge” is an ideal place to “light a candle and say a prayer.”
A historic gift given to the United States by the France to be used a symbol of freedom and democracy. Stands shining in New York City harbor
A performing arts theater located in the heart of Central Park
The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum (often referred to as "TheGuggenheim") is a well-known art museum located on the Upper East Side of Manhattan

column1: The Lion King at the Minskoff Theatre
column3: A fantastic experience to see the performance live with amazing masks / costumes

very popular Irish theme sports bar (opens for breakfast at 10am) with at least 12 large screens showing golf, all american sports plus, big soccer and rugby games, great bar food menu (authentic mexican chefs), good waitress service, very crowded later on after 11pm and the DJ plays it loud till very very late 6am at the weekends, no cover charge getting in, the basement bar is quieter than the ground floor bar.
The Metropolitan Opera is a vibrant home for the most creative and talented artists, including singers, conductors, composers, orchestra musicians, stage directors, designers
The Studio Museum in Harlem is the nexus for artists of African descent locally, nationally and internationally and for work that has been inspired and influenced by black culture.
Times Square is a major commercial intersection in Midtown Manhattan, New York City, at the junction of Broadway and Seventh Avenue
Trinity Church at 79 Broadway, Lower Manhattan, is a historic, active parish church in the Episcopal Diocese of New York.

“Beats the pants” off other fast-fashion chains in true “Japanese style” gush groupies who “stock up” on “fresh-looking” “basics with a stylish twist”, at the “bright, neat” Fifth Avenue flagship and SoHo and 34th Street branches; loyalists “love” the “perfectly stacked” “towers of sweaters”, “special” collaborations with designers including Orla Kiely and Lulu Guinness, “excellent boy-girl versions of jeans” and “innovative products like heat-tech” undies; best of all, it’s “insanely cheap” “without sacrificing quality."
Broadway Show
Home of the New York Yankees
A park which gives you a great view of the New Jersey skyline along the Hudson river
A park which is very pretty and great for the family but should be avoided early in the morning and late at night
A quieter option to the busy Central park and the promenade overlooking the water is very nice to sit and relax.
A beautiful place for kids and grownups, which has movie screenings on summer nights. Great place for a picnic due to its water view.
A botanical garden along the edge of Central Park

This final resting stop for President Ulysses S. Grant – and “the Mrs. too” – is the largest tomb in North America but has only “esoteric appeal” for history and “Civil War buffs”; otherwise, it’s a “long schlep” Uptown with “not much to see” except the Jersey skyline.
An amazing park in the heart of NYC that provides a great view of the Empire State Building.
Street performers frequent this park, and it is a beautiful place to just sit and relax and look at all the architecture around it. Features a triumphal arch.
The location of the occupy wall street movement
A clean quiet peaceful park which makes you feel like you are in a nature wilderness while still being in the middle of the city.

For over a century, this landmark, named for Christopher Columbus and centered around a 70-foot granite column with a statue of the explorer, has been a major intersection at the crossroads of two of NYC’s most famous streets, Broadway and Central Park South; fountains, benches and plant tiers make it an ideal spot to break from shopping or to plan a route through Central Park; P.S. at night the fountains are illuminated by 300 lights, creating a romantic atmosphere that will almost make you forget the traffic circling around you
This park is located right along the Hudson river and offers great views of the New Jersey skyline
Duane Park is a Tribeca Restaurant where you will always be guaranteed a delicious meal and a fabulous show. Real classic Burlesque and Live Jazz on Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays.
Contemporary fine art gallery located at the center of the Chelsea art galleries district. Expert art dealers offer a wide variety of original paintings, sculptures and fine art photography.
An art gallery which features Damien hirst, Richard Serra, Pablo Picasso, jeff Koons and Richard Prince.

Barbara Gladstone's hangar-like 24th St. exhibition space, designed by Selldorf Architects, has helped to make grand spectacles of films by Matthew Barney and Shirin Neshat; sculptures by Anish Kapoor, best known for his reflective Cloud Gate in Chicago; and arrestingly explicit cartoons of Carroll Dunham, among other works by contemporary artists across a range of media.
Features contemporary art from artists like Fernando Botero, Magdalena Abakanowicz and Jacques Lipchitz

James and Jane Cohan exhibit the videos of Bill Viola, the films of Wim Wenders, the intricate and trippy sculptural paintings and photo collages of Fred Tomaselli, and stone floor sculptures of Richard Long, among other works in various media
An art gallery which features Leslie Thorton, Janet Biggs, Jennifer Dalton and other paintings which are oil on canvas

The “best modern art anywhere” is housed in a large Midtown building that offers an extensive display of the museum’s holdings; in addition to six floors of exceptional art arranged around a mammoth atrium, there’s also a much-beloved sculpture garden, gift shops purveying some of the city’s most “unique” items, a first-rate restaurant, The Modern, and two pleasing cafes.

David Maupin and Rachel Lehmann's Rem Koolhaas-designed gallery tends to favor edgy, sexy work by provocateurs (Kara Walker, Gilbert & George, and Tracy Emin whose first New York solo show premiered here), including a handful of punk and indie rocker-artists (Billy Childish, Kim Gordon). If you can't make it to the gallery, it's worth checking out the artist videos on the website.

A pioneer in Chelsea, Matthew Marks is now one of the neighborhood's biggest galleries, showing blue-chip artists such as Ellsworth Kelly and Brice Marden, as well as work by iconoclasts such as Nayland Blake, Nan Goldin, and Inez van Lamsweerde in collaboration with Vinoodh Matadin.

“You don’t have to be Jewish to love” this twosome’s “wonderful array of Judaica”, with the main museum store showcasing “desirable” “books and baubles” (often “reflecting the current exhibit”), while its neighbor is “nice” for “high-quality” “holiday and ritual” pieces; “look no further” for a “meaningful” “remembrance”, especially if money’s “no object.”
Currently closed for renovation, Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, is the only museum in the nation devoted exclusively to historic and contemporary design. Scheduled to reopen in 2014.

column1: The Whitney Museum of American Art
column3: Specializing in American art of the 20th and 21st centuries, this East Side museum manages the neat trick of being “intimate and world-class at the same time” given its “perfect size” and “distinctive” permanent collection; some of its “avant-garde” work can be “puzzling” and even “shocking”, but most agree it’s “required viewing for a modern art lover.”
Both an art gallery and history museum, the Museum of Sex honors the History, Evolution and Cultural Significance of Human Sexuality.

For something “refreshingly different from the typical”, this “innovative” LES museum lobby nook stocks “specialty art and design books” centered on the contempo scene, as well as “irreverent and clever” “nifty-gifties” and tees conceived by rising talents; critics dis the “uninformed” staff, but even they concede it’s “totally worth a look-see” for an edgy keepsake.

For a “fascinating” “history of early immigrants”, explore this 1863 “preserved tenement” containing the re-created apartments of three families from the 1870s, 1910s and 1930s; there’ll be “no complaining about today’s rentals when you see how people once lived.”

This subtle, lovely, and fascinating museum is in, of all places, the space once occupied by the Women's Department of Barneys. It is about as far from retail as you could imagine. The museum is dedicated to the art of the Himalayas, and in this case that term has a broad geographical reach, stretching all the way from India to Mongolia. You won't find such a wide array of art from Tibet, India, Nepal, Bhutan, Pakistan, Afghanistan, and Burma in one place anywhere else in this hemisphere. The museum's permanent collection of over 2,000 works is enhanced and supplemented by a changing series of exhibits of art from other museums. The collection, which includes small brass and silver statues of deities, textiles, costumes, wall (or tent) hangings, and paintings is astonishing. The lighting and presentation of the art is elegant. I would recommend going through the museum with a guide. (Call ahead for times or to schedule.) The guide I had was wonderful. You may not walk out of this museum a Buddhist, but I would be very surprised if you didn't leave with some sense of enlightenment. The museum also has a stylish yet welcoming cafe that serves a selection of food from the countries of the Himalayan region. Note: On Friday evenings, the cafe becomes the K2 Lounge, where you can hang out, have a rotating special like the Dragon Eyes Mojito and, with a $7 bar minimum, see a movie at the museum for free

For the “little scientist” or the “young at heart”, this triple-tiered store in the “landmark” Upper West Side museum is “a learning experience and a pleasure” with its “impressive” variety of “fun” “souvenirs” (“all the dinosaurs you could want”), “educational toys”, “unique jewelry” and “interesting finds” at “doable prices”; it’s a quarry for “offbeat” gifts “whether you’re a tourist or a lifelong NYer”, but beware “when school’s out” and “the masses descend.”
Located in New York City, the world's first and foremost vertical metropolis, The Skyscraper Museum celebrates the City's rich architectural heritage & historical forces that have shaped its skyline.

column1: New-York Historical Society Museum and Library
column3: A trip to New York is not complete without a visit to the New-York Historical Society, where 400 years of history, artifacts and art tell the story of America through the eyes of New York.
The NYC Fire Museum displays illustrate the evolution of firefighting. Features antique fire trucks, firefighting tools and permanent 9-11 memorial room.

A branch of the Smithsonian, this “smaller museum” opposite Battery Park features “free exhibits of Native American history and art”; more impressive for some is its “beautiful beaux arts” building, the former U.S. Custom House designed by Cass Gilbert and featuring Reginald Marsh murals in its stunning rotunda.
Museum exhibitions explore Jewish life in the 20th and 21st centuries—before, during, and after the Holocaust. Acclaimed talks, films, and performances highlight the richness of Jewish culture.

A dynamic home for jazz and people who either love it, are curious about it, or don't know that they are yet! Free classes, exhibits, lectures, plus a chance to meet and mix with similarly minded folk
A library and museum featuring works by Anna Hyatt Huntington and Archer Milton Huntington.

This Seaport-area site was built between 1909 and 1911 as the home of NYC’s First Precinct and today serves as a museum tracing the history of the NYPD and showcasing its unique role in city life past and present; it offers exhibitions, educational programs and extensive activities for children, and serves as a memorial for officers who lost their lives in the line of duty, including those who died on 9/11.

“Relatively small” yet definitely “worthwhile”, this “serious” East Side museum focuses on all things Asian and features “art objects one wouldn’t ordinarily see” – exhibitions have showcased everything from Japanese screens of the Edo period to contemporary video works; this “Zen-inducing” place is “graciousness personified”, even if its “esoteric” holdings may be mostly geared toward “intellectual” types.
A museum which features Ukranian folk art as well as their wood carved cultural heritage.

The National Academy Museum in NYC is dedicated to creating and preserving a living history of American Art. The museum houses a collection of over 7,000 works from the 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries.

This Smithsonian-affiliated Wall Street museum explores the past, present and future of the country’s financial life with an eye toward education while also celebrating America’s economic history – including NYC’s role as the nation’s (and arguably the world’s) financial center; visitors can view artifacts and learn about early entrepreneurs, the stock market, financial scandals, business crises and more.

column1: Rose Center for Earth and Space
column3: The Rose Center uses state of the art technology to reveal the wonders of the Universe through a series of simulations and interactive displays. Visitors are shown a simulation of the creation of the universe and the Big Bang, including a narration by Jodie Foster. A spiralling walkway circling the sphere chronicles the 13-billion year evolution of the universe, with images taken from the Hubble telescope.The highlight of the exhibition is undoubtedly the Space Show inside the Hayden Planatarium. A 30-minute 3-D tour of the universe, using the world's most powerful virtual reality simulator, takes audiences past Mars, Jupiter and Saturn to witness the birth of stars in another galaxy and come face-to-face with a Black Hole. Arrive early if you want to buy tickets for a show on the same day, or phone the ticket hotline to buy tickets in advance. A limited number of tickets can also be purchased from the Rose Center Website.The Rose Center is located in the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan's Upper West Side, overlooking Central Park. It stages numerous exhibitions throughout the year and lots of fun events.
George Washington bid farewell to his officers at this refurbished colonial-era home turned tavern; today, it's a museum detailing 18th-century history with a restaurant/bar below.
More than a museum, Discovery Times Square is the destination for discovery through unique and immersive exhibits in New York. Here, events epic and rare come to life.

Visitors “wax eloquent” about the “amazingly lifelike” waxen renditions of their “favorite celebs” – some 200 of them, from Marie Antoinette to Beyoncé – at this sprawling Times Square attraction; while some say it’s “overpriced” just to ogle a “bunch of stiffs”, most call it an “amusing experience” rife with “fun Kodak moments.”

column1: Museum of Comic and Cartoon Art
column3: A museum featuring the history of comic and cartoon art with works by artists such as Todd Mcfarlane.
A great theatrical performance which features puppetry and a creative storyline

Branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art that was constructed out of sections of French medieval monasteries, offers an extensive collection of statues, paintings, stained glass windows and tapestries.

All aboard for the saucy and splendid new production of one of the greatest musicals in Broadway history. Cole Porter’s classic stars Tony Award® winner Sutton Foster (Thoroughly Modern Millie, The Drowsy Chaperone) and Tony Award and Academy Award® winner Joel Grey (Cabaret, Wicked), and is directed and choreographed by Tony Award winner Kathleen Marshall (The Pajama Game, Grease)! As the S.S. American heads out to sea, two unlikely pairs set off on the course to true love…proving that sometimes destiny needs a little help from a crew of singing sailors, an exotic disguise and some good old-fashioned blackmail. Peppering this hilariously bumpy ride are some musical theatre’s most memorable standards, including “I Get A Kick out of You,” “It’s De-lovely” and of course, “Anything Goes.”

Dedicated to helping locals and visitors alike enjoy the unique wonders of New York City, Classic Harbor Line hopes for the privilege of escorting you on a relaxing, inspiring and breathtaking cruise through the waters we proudly call home. Our three classic yachts – the Schooner Adirondack and the Schooner Imagine (our sailboats), and the Luxury Yacht Manhattan (our motorized yacht) are reminiscent of the classic boats that cruised the NYC waters a hundred years ago.
A ferry which can be used for sightseeing but also provides free access to Staten Island from the southern tip of Manhattan

New York City Ballet is one of the foremost dance companies in the world, with a roster of spectacular dancers and an unparalleled repertory. The Company was founded in 1948 by George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein, and it quickly became world-renowned for its athletic and contemporary style. Jerome Robbins joined NYCB the following year and, with Balanchine, helped to build the astounding repertory and firmly establish the Company in New York.
A museum which strives to imitate what the journey through immigration on Ellis Island would be like.

The Museum at Eldridge Street based in the National Historic Landmark Eldridge Street Synagogue, presents the culture, history and traditions of Jewish immigrants on the Lower East Side drawing parallels with the diverse cultural communities that have settled in America.

The Shuberts conceived of the Imperial Theatre, their fiftieth New York venue, as a home to musical theatre hits, and their dream has been realized many times over. The playhouse was constructed as a replacement for the Shubert’s 20 year old (and out-of-date) Lyric Theatre.
